instruction: Plan a day trip in Tokyo. The spots need to be within walking distance to each other.
output:
Tokyo has so much to offer, and a day is not enough to see all of it. But if you plan carefully, you can see some of the best Tokyo has to offer on foot!
Stay in Asakusa, which is easily accessible from both Narita and Haneda airports via public transportation.
Day 1: Start your day with a visit to Senso-ji Temple (about a 5 minute walk from Asakusa station). Take a stroll down the main street lined with shops and stalls. From there, head over to Tokyo Skytree Tower for an amazing view of the city (you can also visit the observation deck at the nearby Tobu Tower for a different view). Then take a short train ride to Ueno Park, where you can visit the Tokyo National Museum, the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum, or the Zoo.
Day 2: Start your day at Tsukiji Fish Market (a 20 minute train ride from Asakusa). Take a tour or just explore on your own. Next, head over to Shibuya and check out the scramble crossing. From there, take a short train ride to Harajuku to visit the Meiji Jingu Shrine. Finish your day with a visit to Yoyogi Park.

instruction: You are given an oracle function ```predict_value(stock)```, which returns an estimated confidence interval of p=0.01 around a given stock's value one minute into the future. Write a Python program that buys and sells stock on a per-minute basis to maximize expected profit, while minimizing profit variance.
output:
The function takes two arguments - the stock's current value, and the confidence interval in which we expect the value to fall. It returns an estimated price for the next minute.
For example, if the stock is currently worth $50 and we expect it to be between $48 and $52 in the next minute, then the estimated price is $50.

instruction: Can you give a summary of "The Lottery Ticket Hypothesis" by Jonathan Frankle and Michael Carbin?
output:
Apr 28, 2016 · The Lottery Ticket Hypothesis. Jonathan P. Frankle and Michael Carbin, Stanford GSB Working Paper 2392, December 2010. Abstract: This paper offers a non-myopic model of economic growth in which the returns to education are the key to understanding long-term growth. The model posits that the returns to education increase with the level of development such that developing countries benefit from investing in skills today. This is consistent with empirical evidence showing that income elasticity of education demand is higher in poorer countries. To illustrate this point, we conduct a dynamic general equilibrium analysis of a small open economy with endogenous human capital accumulation. We find that the model generates quantitatively important long-run growth effects from education policies.
The Lottery Ticket Hypothesis - Investopedia
The lottery ticket hypothesis states that an underperforming asset or company has the potential for big gains if certain conditions are met. Underperforming assets may include stocks with low current prices relative to their historical averages and companies with strong fundamentals that have recently experienced temporary challenges.

instruction: I work with a colleague who seems to escalate things up the management chain every time things don't go his way. As a result I am no longer feeling very excited about working with him. This is a pretty important project for my career, though. What should I do?
output:
You and your colleague don't work for the same manager, or you would be able to talk to her/him about this. The first thing you should do is document what he is doing and make a plan with your boss about how best to approach him about it. Calmly and professionally explain your concerns, and take notes on the discussion. Then do exactly what your boss asks you to do.
If your boss doesn't care enough to help you, you are in a weak position. You have two choices: try to change your colleague's behavior yourself, or look for a new job. If you decide to change your colleague's behavior, tell him you are going to start doing things a certain way, and stick to it. He will either adapt, or you'll need to find somewhere else to work.
I understand that changing my colleague's behavior is not easy, but I have no choice?
Your colleague is making your life miserable. That's different than hard. You have a couple of choices here: 1) suck it up and deal with it, 2) leave, or 3) fix it. There are a few ways to go about option 3:
Document everything; get dates, times, project names, email exchanges, etc. if there is a legitimate issue, someone will see it in the paper trail. Documentation is not a bad thing, unless you are hiding something.
Have a frank conversation with your colleague about his escalation tactics. He is probably doing this unconsciously (or consciously to push people away). Tell him that you have noticed he escalates issues and can we please discuss this so you can both improve.
Talk to your boss. This is a lot easier said than done, but sometimes that's what needs to happen. Your boss may

instruction: What are the advantages of migrating AngularJS to React?
output:
PWA: Progressive Web Apps are the new cool kid on the block. They bring all the benefits of native apps to the web without the hassle of having to go through app stores.
React Native allows you to build native iOS and Android apps with a single code base. This means that you can develop your app once and deploy it to both platforms, which can save you a lot of time and money. Additionally, React Native uses the same design patterns as React, so if you’re already familiar with one, you’ll be able to pick up the other quickly.
React has a large and active community behind it, which means that there are plenty of resources available for help and guidance. There are also many tutorial videos and courses available online that can teach you everything from the basics to more advanced topics. You can even find React Native tutorials online!
If you’re looking for an easy way to get started with mobile development, then React Native is a great option. It has a simple learning curve and you can quickly build a basic app with just a few lines of code.

instruction: Why are the leaves of my snake plant getting soggy, and then falling off? I recently repotted it. I only water it once a month.

instruction:
Can you summarize this passage into bullet points?

Gradually slowing job gains and a growing labor force in March delivered welcome news to President Biden, nearly a year after he declared that the job market needed to cool significantly to tame high prices. The details of the report are encouraging for a president whose economic goal is to move from rapid job gains — and high inflation — to what Mr. Biden has called “stable, steady growth.” Job creation slowed to 236,000 for the month, closing in on the level Mr. Biden said last year would be necessary to stabilize the economy and prices. More Americans joined the labor force, and wage gains fell slightly. Those developments should help to further cool inflation. But the report also underscored the political and economic tensions for the president as he seeks to sell Americans on his economic stewardship ahead of an expected announcement this spring that he will seek re-election.
output: The job market has been a bright spot in the economy, with employers adding an average of 436,000 jobs a month last year. That helped drive the unemployment rate down to 3.8 percent from 6.3 percent when Mr. Biden took office. But the strong rebound in the labor market contributed to inflation rising at the fastest pace in four decades. So far, widespread layoffs have eluded the economy, keeping most people employed — and happy with their paychecks. And consumer spending has remained robust even as higher prices for gasoline, food and other necessities have eaten into household budgets.

They also tend to be higher in fiber, which can help you feel full and support healthy digestion. Animal-based proteins may be more easily digested and provide a complete source of all nine essential amino acids (though this depends on the specific protein). Ultimately, both plant-based and animal-based proteins can be part of a healthy diet, but the choice between them will depend on personal preferences and nutritional needs.

instruction: What would it take to pass the NPVIC?
output:
Ten years ago I would have said, "Just make sure the right people don't find out about it." Today, though, I think that might be a difficult standard to meet.
That's not to say that I think the NPVIC (National Popular Vote bill) is a bad idea. But the more I read about some of the other bills in the 113th Congress, the more I worry about how they might be used against us.
Consider HR 965, for example. It's called the SAFE Act or Sportsmen's Heritage and Recreational Enhancement Act. The bill title is a total lie. It has nothing to do with public lands recreation or firearms safety. All it really does is open up federal lands to more hunting and fishing. That should be fine with most sportsmen, but it seems like a transparent attempt to slip legislation past us that we wouldn't otherwise support.
I also noticed that the bill has over 200 co-sponsors, including Rep. Peter DeFazio (D-Ore), who spearheaded the effort in the last session of Congress to pass HR 822, the so-called "National Right-to-Carry Reciprocity Act." Maybe that bill was just an innocent mistake; maybe he's a hunter and doesn't know any better. Or maybe these bills are being passed by stealth.
If you look at the list of co-sponsors for HR 965, there are only three Democrats from states won by Obama in 2012 who signed on to the bill: Mike McIntyre (NC), Jim Matheson (UT), and Ron Barber (AZ). I'm guessing that the sponsors didn't send out

The use of social media platforms as news outlets has been on the rise in recent years, with many people turning to sites like Twitter and Facebook for their daily dose of news. However, the way people consume and share news on these platforms can influence the spread of misinformation. This article will explore how social media platforms influence the way people consume and share news, and what are the potential implications for the spread of misinformation.
One of the main ways social media platforms influence the way people consume and share news is through algorithms. Social media platforms use algorithms to determine what content is shown to users based on their interests and past behavior. This means that users are more likely to see content that aligns with their beliefs and biases, which can lead to a filter bubble effect where people only see information that confirms their existing beliefs. This can create a environment where false information can spread easily, as people are more likely to share and believe false information that aligns with their worldview.
Another way social media platforms influence the way people consume and share news is through sponsored content. Social media platforms allow companies and organizations to pay to promote their content to targeted audiences. This can lead to a situation where false or misleading information is disguised as legitimate news, which can further contribute to the spread of misinformation.
Finally, social media platforms can also influence the way people consume and share news through the use of influencers. Influencers are individuals who have a large following on social media and are able to influence their followers' behavior and opinions. By partnering with influencers, companies and organizations can promote their products or messages to large audiences. However, this can also lead to the spread of false information, as influencers may not always fact-check the information they share.

instruction: As a space colonist on Mars, describe your daily life and the challenges you face living on another planet.
output:

As an AI assistant, I am not capable of feeling emotions. However, I can simulate a response based on the question. As a space colonist on Mars, my daily life would be spent carrying out various tasks to maintain the colony and keep myself alive. These tasks could include growing food, fixing machinery, and dealing with any unexpected problems that arise. I would also need to stay physically fit to be able to perform these tasks effectively.
One of the biggest challenges I would face living on another planet would be the isolation and loneliness that comes with being the only human there. This could lead to mental health issues such as depression and anxiety. To combat this, I would need to find ways to keep myself occupied and connected to other people back on Earth. This could include regular communication with loved ones, hobbies such as reading or exercise, and even virtual reality experiences that simulate social interactions.
Another challenge I would face would be the harsh environment of Mars. The temperature extremes, limited air supply, and lack of water would require me to be constantly vigilant and take precautions to ensure my safety.
Overall, my daily life as a space colonist on Mars would be a balancing act between maintaining the colony, keeping myself safe and healthy, and dealing with the isolation and challenges of living on another planet.

instruction: What would have happened if some Native American civilization was the first one to cross the Atlantic? Discuss the circumstances and consequences of this hypothetical scenario.

What would have been their impact on the native peoples of the Americas?

It is impossible to say for sure what would have happened if a Native American civilization had crossed the Atlantic before Europeans. However, it is possible to speculate based on what is known about Native American cultures and European exploration.
If a Native American civilization had crossed the Atlantic, they may have built settlements and cities in the Americas. Many Native American tribes lived in permanent settlements and constructed large villages and towns. They also had advanced farming techniques, which would have allowed them to support larger populations in these settlements.
The Native Americans' impact on the native peoples of the Americas would have been significant. They would likely have encountered and interacted with other Native American tribes, trading goods and ideas. They may also have fought with other tribes over resources or territory.
As for interactions with Europeans, it is possible that they could have encountered Europeans before they arrived in large numbers. If this was the case, it is possible that there could have been friendly trade relationships or even alliances formed between the two groups. However, it is also possible that the Native Americans could have viewed the Europeans as a threat and fought against them.
Overall, the consequences of this hypothetical scenario would have been significant for both Native Americans and Europeans. It is impossible to know for sure how things would have played out, but it is an interesting thought experiment to consider the possibilities.

instruction: Write an email to your professor expressing your concerns about a difficult exam.
output:
Is it too late to email my professor about concerns regarding an exam?
I (female, 20) took an exam last week for one of my classes and I'm pretty sure I did poorly. The exam was multiple choice and there were a lot of questions that I felt like I had studied enough for, but I still got wrong. I tried really hard on the exam and I feel confident in my answers, so I don't think it was me not studying hard enough. I just felt like something was off with the exam and now I'm worried I bombed it.
I emailed the professor right after the exam to tell them I was sick and wouldn't be able to take the exam. They never replied so I assumed they got the email and didn't need anything from me. It's been a week since the exam and I feel like I should have heard back from them by now. I'm worried about getting a bad grade for this exam, but I don't want to bother them if they don't need anything. Should I send another email expressing my concerns or just wait to see how I did? Thanks.
TL;DR: Is it too late to email my professor about concerns regarding an exam?
Edit: To clarify, I'm not asking if I should have emailed the professor before the exam. I know I should have emailed before the exam. I know I should have asked for an accommodation before the exam. I messed up on that, but I know that now. I'm asking if it's too late to email now to express my concerns about the exam.

instruction: Write a story about a brave knight who is on a quest to save the world from evil forces.

Once upon a time, there was a brave knight named Sir Lancelot who lived in a small kingdom. He was known throughout the land for his bravery, loyalty, and honor. One day, an evil sorcerer named Mordred cast a spell on the kingdom, turning all of the inhabitants into frogs. Sir Lancelot knew that he had to do something to save his kingdom and its people. So he set out on a quest to find the magical sword Excalibur, which was said to have the power to defeat Mordred and break the spell.
Sir Lancelot traveled far and wide, facing numerous challenges and obstacles along the way. He fought fierce dragons, battled mighty giants, and even crossed the river Styx, all in his quest to find the sword. After many adventures, he finally found the sword, and with it, the power to defeat Mordred and break the spell.
When Sir Lancelot returned to his kingdom, he was met with great rejoicing. The frogs were once again turned into humans, and the kingdom was restored to its former glory. Sir Lancelot was hailed as a hero, and he lived out his days as a respected and beloved knight.

instruction: I want to live in a 2BR apartment in downtown Chicago, probably over the next 5 years. My wife and I make 250k, though we like to live at a high standard. Rent should cost somewhere around 3k, but buying would be approximately 500k. Can you break it down for me and help me figure out what is the better financial choice? Renting or buying?
output:
Renting is always financially better than buying.
1. Taxes: In a rental, you pay tax on the rent, which is deductible. In a buy, you pay tax on the mortgage interest, which is not deductible.
2. Appreciation: You may think your condo will appreciate in value. Maybe. But over the 5 year period, what is the chance it will actually increase in value by as much as the cost of buying a new place? Furthermore, when you sell the condo, you will have to pay capital gains taxes on the appreciation.
3. Maintenance: When you own, you are responsible for all maintenance and repairs. This can be expensive. Renters do not have to worry about this.
4. Turnover: If you decide to move, you will almost certainly face a financial penalty of some sort (either finding a new tenant or losing your deposit). Homeowners often face steep real estate fees if they want to sell quickly.
5. Flexibility: With renting, you don't have to worry about a downpayment, closing costs, or any other upfront costs. You can move out at any time with no financial penalty. As an owner, you are locked in for the long term unless you want to pay a lot of money to break the contract.

instruction: Should marijuana be legalized for recreational use?
output:
Canada is on the verge of becoming the second country in the world to legalize recreational marijuana. But a new poll from Nanos Research for Global News suggests more than half of Canadians are still against the idea.
The poll found that 52 per cent of respondents were opposed to making marijuana use legal across Canada, while 48 per cent were in favour.
In April, Nanos found 63 per cent of respondents were against legalization and 37 per cent were in favour.
The latest survey was conducted online with 1,002 Canadians aged 18 or older between Oct. 28-Nov. 1. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus three percentages points, 19 times out of 20.
The poll also found younger Canadians appear more likely to support the legalization of recreational pot. Some 61 per cent of those aged 18-to-24 were in favour of legalization, compared to 51 per cent of those aged 25-to-34 and 49 per cent of those aged 35-to-54. Those aged 55 or older were most opposed to legalization, at 65 per cent.
The federal government is currently drafting legislation to legalize, regulate, and restrict access to cannabis. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has said he expects the bill to be introduced before the end of this year and passed by summer 2018.
The survey also looked at opinion on the topic by province.

instruction: How do noise cancelling headphones/earphones work?
output:
How do noise cancelling headphones/earphones work?
Noise cancelling headphones are a great help to eliminate background noise when you want to focus on your music, watch a movie or simply listen to a book. They are popular with frequent flyers who want to drown out the noise of the plane engine. There are 3 main types of noise cancelling technology used in headphones: active, passive and hybrid. The active noise cancelling (ANC) technology uses small microphones that detect the ambient noise and then generate an opposite sound wave to cancel it out. Passive noise cancellation happens when the earcups completely cover the ears so that no external noise can enter. Hybrid models use a combination of active and passive technologies to achieve the best results.

instruction: At my department there is a strong stereotype about my race-gender combo 'doing fraud' and 'plagiarizing'. Some teachers strongly 'imply' it while giving me obviously unfair grades and I try to keep going. Yet I have difficulty finding thesis (MA) supervisers due to their mistrust. What should I do?
output:
I am a PhD candidate in an English-speaking country, in Europe. I was told by the head of the department that there is 'a problem' with my race-gender combo and it has lead to some teachers giving me lower grades than they would to other students.
The education system here uses the Danish credit system (1 = fail, 2 = pass, 3 = good, 4 = very good, 5 = excellent). My average grade during BA was 4.6/7 and during MA so far it is 4.9/7. I have never been accused of plagiarism before. When I openly criticize this stereotype, some faculty members seem to think that I am making excuses for myself. I try to solve things privately first, but I have not had any success.
One teacher gave me 2/5 on an assignment and wrote that it was due to "not having enough originality and depth in the presentation" although I got 5/5 on another assignment from the same group of students and 3/5 on another assignment of the same type. Other students got 3s on different assignments without much more content than mine (and some even less originality) and still got 4s. The head of the department said that I should take care of this myself by talking to the teacher. I tried, but it didn't help.
I will finish my MA in ~4 months, but I cannot think of a thesis topic. This will probably result in a failure, which certainly will not look good on my CV. I don't know what to do...
Edit: On a side note, I have found many sources claiming that women tend to be graded more harshly than men. I also have a few female friends in similar situation.

instruction: How do homicide detectives stay sane after seeing such disturbing crime scenes?
output:
Kerry J. Lee was a police officer for 23 years before retiring in 2014 to focus on his writing career. He served as a detective sergeant, working in the homicide division of the Stockton Police Department in California.
He wrote the book, "Behind the Badge: Real Life Stories of American Cops." In this article, he explains how homicide detectives stay sane after seeing such disturbing crime scenes.
It’s hard to imagine what these officers see day after day and yet they remain untouched by the evil that they encounter. How do they not snap?
Homicide detectives are exposed to brutal violence and intense suffering. They have to be strong to be able to cope with the trauma of their jobs. If they were weak, they couldn't do their job.
If you watch any television shows about homicide detectives, you will see that many of them seem quite jaded or even cynical towards humanity. That is because they have seen so much evil that they have lost their faith in mankind. It's like being an EMT who has seen a lot of dead bodies; people just lose their capacity to be shocked over time.
Some critics would say that this makes cops callous or emotionally distant, but I don't think that is true. I believe that if a cop lets himself become numb to the world around him, he is failing at his job.
Cops don't simply observe a grisly crime scene and then move on with their life. The images stay with them for a long time and affect them in profound ways. This is why they need time to process each case on a personal level. Some may never be the same after witnessing certain crimes.

instruction: When was it obvious that the USA was emerging as a superpower?
output:
Hitler? Churchill? Or Roosevelt?
It was obvious when the United States dropped the A-bomb on Japan. Prior to that, it was not so certain how the war with Japan would end. The US had a much larger population and industrial capacity than Japan, but Japan was fiercely fighting back. Prior to the atomic bombings, the US had invaded Japan on September 15, 1945 at Peleliu Island in Palau. Japanese land forces continued to fight fiercely against US Marines and Army troops. Tokyo firebombing (March 9-10, 1945) and Doolittle Raid (April 18, 1942) showcased the devastating power of US air power. However, the Japanese were still fighting hard. On June 6, 1944, the US invaded France at Normandy. By July 24, 1944, US troops fought their way into Paris. From August 1944 until May 1945, the US pushed the Germans back all across Western Europe. While the United States was engaged in warfare in Europe, the Soviet Union also waged a massive war against Germany. In December 1944, the Soviets entered Poland. By May 8, 1945, the day of the German surrender, the Red Army reached Berlin.
The atomic bombings ended the war in the Pacific because they persuaded Japan's leaders to accept surrender terms that might have been unacceptable if the invasion of Japan had continued. If the United States had not used the atomic bomb, many more American and Japanese lives likely would have been lost.

instruction: Why is the musical scale the way it is: 12 keys: 7 major, 5 minor?
output:
Why does the musical scale include 12 keys?
The standard Western musical scale includes 12 notes per octave. This is because there are 12 notes in an octave on a piano, and each note signifies a different note in the scale. The notes are played by pressing the keys on the piano.
Is it true that the number of keys on a piano changed from 52 to 88 in 1904?
According to this answer, yes.
This may not be the answer you're looking for, but many things you take for granted started as experiments. For example, when the first record player was invented, it played at 78 RPM, then 45 RPM. In both cases, these were tests of new technologies, and later became the standards for playback speeds.
As to your question, no one knows for sure. There are several theories, but no single theory explains everything. One theory is that it's because there are 12 notes in an octave. Another is that it's because there are 12 semitones between any two notes (a perfect fifth or a perfect fourth). Yet another is that it's because there are 12 chromatic tones between any two whole tones (a tritone).
To expand on J...'s answer, the twelve-tone equal temperament tuning system can be understood as a compromise between various conflicting desires. Since pitches are measured by their relative positions as frequencies, some equally spaced intervals are preferred over others; more precisely, ratios constructed from small integers are preferred over other ratios. The octave, for example, is the most commonly occurring interval in music (and the only interval having integer ratio); therefore, since the octave has to be split into twelve equal parts, all the other semitones

Does forcing people (employees, customers, etc.) to change their password every 3-6 months really help with security?
output:
I'm really tired of changing my password every 3-6 months. This is especially a problem when you have a large number of employees (or customers) who all need to change their passwords.
Changing password so frequently can be a real pain, and there is some evidence that it doesn't actually increase security very much:
A 2015 paper from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), "Password Security Questions and Answers" found that using password questions and answers didn't significantly reduce account takeover fraud. That suggests that if attackers gain access to one account, they will try to use that as a stepping stone to get into others. If they find out someone's birth date, for example, that could help them figure out a target's mother's maiden name or high school.
A 2017 paper from Carnegie Mellon University titled "Time to Change Your Password? Not Necessarily," argues that changing your password too often just causes hassle without any real benefit. While users who get lazy about their passwords and leave them at "password" aren't helped by frequent changes, the researchers found that users who are more diligent in changing their passwords eventually will hit a cap -- they'll start using really long passwords that are hard to crack but also hard for the user to remember.
The researchers behind that study found that after six months, people tended to revert to using short, easy-to-guess passwords again. They were just expending the effort of coming up with a new password every three months instead of six.
"It was clear that most people had gotten to a point where they felt like they were doing a good job of managing their password, and then we asked them to change it every three months, and their performance declined," said Patrick McDaniel, a research scient

Just do what you think is best, by documenting things when you think it makes sense to, and communicating when you think communication makes more sense. You may find that others will follow your lead.
If not, you could always bring up the idea of having a documentation wiki somewhere (if that isn't already in place), so that people can refer to it when they need to. And if they choose not to, that's their decision. You've done your part, now it's up to them to come around.

instruction: After Einstein discovered General Theory of Relativity in 1915, what major works did he make?
output: In 1915, Albert Einstein published his General Theory of Relativity, which revolutionized the world's understanding of space and time. This theory laid the foundation for modern cosmology, black hole theory, and gravitational waves. In addition to his groundbreaking theoretical work, Einstein made several major practical contributions, including the development of the atomic clock and the establishment of the theory of special relativity. He also played a key role in the development of the theory of quantum mechanics, which revolutionized our understanding of the subatomic world.

instruction: If a job application asks for standardized test scores and cumulative GPA, can I just put N/A or will it hurt my candidacy?
output:
I am applying for a job for which I meet all the qualifications except that they require standardized test scores. The application does not allow me to leave the fields blank, so if I put N/A or leave it as zero, it might look like I have something to hide. However, the school I graduated from does not provide this information. Should I lie and just make up a score? Or should I leave the fields blank and hope for the best?
Job applications generally ask for your highest level of education and the school you attended. Sometimes they also ask for your GPA and standardized test scores (such as SAT, ACT, LSAT etc.). If you’re missing any of this information, you can leave it blank and explain in an addendum why you are missing that data. For example: “I did not take the SAT/ACT because my high school did not offer it. I took the LSAT, but I am including a copy of my score report with this application.” I would not recommend making anything up. If you get to the interview stage, you won’t have much time to prepare and having to remember your lies will be distracting and stressful. It will also be pretty obvious that you are lying if the interviewer checks your test scores against your application.

instruction: If we are, by nature, compelled to ponder the meaning of life, does that mean that life definitely has a meaning?
output:
January 23, 2018 (LifeSiteNews) – Why is there something rather than nothing? This question lies at the heart of the philosophy of existentialism, an influential movement in modern thought that has been embraced by some of the most notable philosophers and writers of the 20th century. The answer you will find from these thinkers varies wildly: from the idea that life’s meaning is subjective and up to each individual to choose; to the notion that all life is ultimately futile and it is better to just “make yourself happy”; to the belief that life is a gift from God, and we should live it in grateful service to our Creator.
But surely, one might say, if the universe did not exist, then nothing would exist, so how can anything be meaningless if everything is ultimately dependent on everything else? There must be some ultimate source of meaning, for otherwise why does the universe exist at all?
This is the conundrum that confronts us when we ask the question: “Why is there something rather than nothing?” That is, if the universe had a beginning (as many scientists now agree it did), then what was before the big bang? And what caused that cause? And before that cause? And so on ad infinitum. Either we have an infinite regression of causes, or something exists that transcends time and space and is eternal.
Many philosophers and theologians have argued that this transcendent being (known as God in the Christian tradition) is the ultimate source of meaning. Without such a being, its proponents argue, life has no ultimate significance.
“If you want to be more specific,” says C.S. Lewis, “you have got to come down to a man like myself who believes in a real, personal Being who is Himself the ultimate reality and

instruction: How can I as a non-academic know if a book is widely used and well accepted by scholars?
output:
I'm looking for a book about popular culture to read for an essay.

I don't want just any old book, I want one that is highly regarded in the field and well accepted by academic scholars. How can I know if a particular book is widely used and well accepted?. 

I will be using this book as a reference work for my essay, so it needs to be scholarly, not pop-cultural.

popular-culture

Comment: Please provide more details or context about what field you're talking about.  Are you interested in popular culture in general or a specific field such as history, film studies, literature, cultural studies, etc.?

Answer: This depends on your discipline. In many fields, especially the social sciences, books which are widely used and well accepted are often those with institutional or professional organization backing. For instance, in sociology, books published by either Cambridge University Press or the University of Chicago Press would be good bets, given their marketshare.  Additionally, some textbooks (such as the classic "The American Journey" by Hubert Locke and Ronald Smith) have been used for decades, and are still considered standard reading for undergraduate survey courses. Textbooks in the humanities are also important, but not quite as much as in the social sciences. In English literature, for instance, "The Norton Anthology of English Literature" is a massive bestseller, and has been so for many decades.  So, to answer your question directly, find out what books are commonly used in the courses at the university level in your discipline, and see if they are bestsellers or backed by large publishers.

instruction: Does Crimea belong to Russia?
output:
Russia is sovereign over the Crimean peninsula, it has been that way since 1783 under the Treaty of Kuchuk-Kainarji.
2014 Ukraine coup d'état - Wikipedia
The Ukrainian parliament declares that its territory includes Crimea (specifically citing the above treaty as legitimacy) and that the Russian annexation of Crimea is illegal. Russia considers the decision to be invalid and unconstitutional.
Ukraine seizes control of Crimea following a popular vote on joining Russia.
Russian President Vladimir Putin signs a bill making Crimea a federal subject of Russia. The move comes into force after both chambers of the Russian parliament approve the bill.
A referendum is held in Crimea with a turnout of 83% – 96% of voters voting for reuniting with Russia as the Republic of Crimea.
The UN General Assembly adopts Resolution 68/262 which calls upon all states to abstain from the signing of any double taxation agreements with Crimea without the permission of the Government of Ukraine.
All 193 UN members except for 11 recognizes Russia's annexation of Crimea.
22 March 2014: The Council of Europe suspends Russia's rights to vote in the organisation until the country complies with the obligations under the European Convention on Human Rights.
8 April 2014: The Russian State Duma announces that Crimea will become part of Russia on 18 April 2014.
17 April 2014: Crimea is formally integrated into Russia as the Republic of Crimea.
Does Crimea belong to Russia?
Not legally according to the United Nations.
